Planarity effect of polychlorinated biphenyls adsorption by graphene nanomaterials: The influence of graphene characteristics, solution pH and temperature
Wenjie Rena, Haiwei Changa, Tingyu Maob, Ying Tenga,⁎
a Key Laboratory of Soil Environment and Pollution Remediation, Institute of Soil Science, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Nanjing 210008, China b College of Resource and Environmental Engineering, Guizhou University, Guiyang 550025, China
H I G H L I G H T S
• Obvious planarity effect displayed in PCBs adsorption on graphene at 0.01–10 ng L−1. • Surface functionalization of graphene significantly promoted the planarity effect. • Acidic and alkaline conditions notably suppressed the planarity effect on GO. • Solution pH exhibited minimal or negligible impact on the planarity effect on SG. • Low temperature promoted the planarity effect of the adsorption on GO or SG.
G R A P H I C A L A B S T R A C T
A R T I C L E I N F O
Keywords: Graphene Nanomaterial PCBs Adsorption Planarity effect
A B S T R A C T
The adsorption of 6 polychlorinated biphenyl (PCB) congeners by one pristine graphene (GN), and two functionalized graphene nanomaterials (graphene oxide (GO), and sulfonated graphene (SG)) was investigated in the environmentally relevant pg-µg L−1 concentration range. Influence of solution pH and temperature on planarity effect of PCBs adsorption on GO and SG was subsequently assessed. GN exhibited stronger adsorption capacities than GO and SG, mainly due to the higher contribution of surface adsorption. Obvious planarity effect displayed in the adsorption of PCBs congeners on the three graphene nanomaterials at low aqueous concentrations (0.01–10 ng L−1) whereas gradually diminished with the increase of aqueous concentration. Interestingly, functionalized graphene illustrated greater planarity effect than pristine GN, especially at the lower concentrations. Compared with neutral condition, acidic or alkaline conditions notably led to the attenuation of the planarity effect on GO through preferable dispersion of GO particles in solution. However, solution pH exhibited minimal or negligible impact on the planarity effect on SG. Low temperature promoted the planarity effect of PCBs adsorption on both functionalized graphene, and the promotion degree on SG was obviously lower than that on GO, while warming resulted in the suppression on the planarity effect.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
In recent years, graphene-based nanomaterials have sparked great interest into potential applications in a wide range of industrial or agricultural fields [1–4], due to unique structure characteristics and extraordinary physicochemical properties. The rapidly increasing production and application are subsequently attracting particular attention to the health and environmental risk of graphene nanomaterials for human beings [5], plants [6], other animals [7] and microorganisms [8]. Meanwhile, the released graphene nanomaterials would interact with concurrent organic pollutants [9], such as polychlorinated biphenyls (PCBs), which are a class of typical persistent organic pollutants and have been reported to be ubiquitous in the environment [10–12]. In that case, graphene nanomaterials would become an effective carrier for these pollutants, thereby potentially affecting their transport, fate and bioavailability in the environment. Consequently, it poses a particular necessity to deeply understand the interaction between graphene-based nanomaterials and these toxic pollutants. Nevertheless, very limited researches have been conducted concerning the adsorption of PCBs by kinds of graphene nanomaterials [13].
As has been suggested by an array of researches, the structural and physiochemical properties of graphene nanomaterials strongly impact the adsorption of hydrophobic organic pollutants (HOCs), such as wrinkles, folds, surface area, pore size distribution, purity and solubility and so on [9,14,15]. Especially, oxygen-containing functional groups play a significant role in the interactions between HOCs and graphene nanomaterials [9]. On one hand, oxygen-containing functional groups can generally make graphene more hydrophilic, consequently suppressing the adsorption of HOCs on graphene due to the competition of water molecules [16]. On the other hand, these functional groups of graphene could also be expected to act as hydrogen-bonding donors and provide additional adsorption sites for HOCs through hydrogenbonding interactions [17]. Moreover, the functional groups might also affect the π-π interaction between graphene and HOC molecules via changing the electronic cloud density of graphene surface as the electron acceptors or donors [18]. In addition to graphene properties, the adsorption of organic compounds on graphene could be highly dependent on aqueous chemistry and environmental conditions, such as solution pH, ionic strength, natural organic matter and temperature [19,20]. Effects of these factors on the adsorption of HOCs by graphene were somewhat HOC-specific, the extents of which were relevant to the ionizability and electron-donor/acceptor ability of the involved HOCs [9].
Planar molecular usually displays stronger adsorption performance than nonplanar molecular even if they have similar solubility or Kow, which was termed as planarity effect [21]. Planarity effect on the adsorption of PCB congeners has been reported in various sorption materials, including black carbon [22], activated carbon [23], nanoplastics, carbon nanotubes, fullerenes [24] and graphene [13]. Furthermore, recent findings have suggested that the effect of molecular planarity resulted in greater influence on PCB adsorption to the nanomaterials than activated carbon and charcoal [13]. Additionally, sorbent properties, aqueous chemistry and environmental conditions might have different effects on the adsorption of planar and nonplanar PCB congeners [23]. Studying adsorption of PCBs by graphene nanomaterials under different conditions is quite crucial for deeply understanding the adsorption mechanisms. However, to the best of our knowledge, no study has examined the effect of solution pH and temperature on PCBs adsorption by graphene nanomaterials.
The objective of the present study was to assess (i) the adsorption of PCB congeners on three types of graphene nanoparticles at realistically low concentrations of 10−5–10−1 µg L−1; (ii) the effect of graphene characteristics and common environmental factors on planarity effect of PCBs adsorption, including solution pH and temperature.

sections.heading: 2.1. Chemicals and sorbents
sections.text:
PCB standards were purchased from AccuStandard (New Haven, Connecticut) with a declared purity of ≥99%, including IUPAC no. 18 (2,2′,5-trichlorobiphenyl), 28 (2,4,4′-trichlorobiphenyl), 53 (2,2′,5,6′- trichlorobiphenyl), 54 (2,2′,6,6′-trichlorobiphenyl), 77 (3,3′,4,4′-tetrachlorobiphenyl), 126 (3,3′,4,4′,5-pentachlorobiphenyl). These congeners were selected due to the following three reasons: (1) to cover the tri- to penta-homolog groups to span a range of log Kow values of 5.24–6.89; (2) to include the congeners (PCBs 18, 28, 77) commonly detected in high frequencies in environmental samples [25,26], especially compounds with high toxicity (PCBs 77, 126) [27]; (3) to include compounds with different degrees of ortho-substitution (PCBs 53, 54, 77) in order to assess effects of molecular planarity (Table S1) [13,23,24]. These congeners also attracted more attention in previous studies [21,23,24,28]. Mixed stock solution of these PCBs congeners were prepared in acetone (HPLC grade, ≥99.8% purity). Other solvents including hexane (HPLC grade, ≥99.8% purity) and methanol (≥99.8% purity) were purchased from Tedia Company (Fairfield, USA).
Polyoxymethylene (POM) sheets (76 µm thickness) were purchased from CS Hyde Co. (Lake Villa, IL). Prior to use, the POM sheets were cut into coupons of desired weight (100mg POM sections with a size of 2×4 cm). POM sections were then washed ultrasonically for 2 h with n-hexane followed by methanol [29]. The extracted POMs were airdried and stored in glass jars with a Teflon-lined lid. No interfering peaks were detected when the washed POM sheets were tested for the 6 analyte PCB congeners. Three types of graphene with different functional groups were applied as sorbents. Graphene (GN) and graphene oxide (GO) were purchased from Nanjing XFNANO Materials Tech Co. Ltd., China. Sulfonated graphene (SG) was kindly supplied by Suzhou Graphene-Tech Co. Ltd., China.

sections.heading: 2.2. Sorbent characterization
sections.text: The microscopic structure and surface morphology of GN, GO and SG were observed by scanning electron microscopy (SEM, S-3400N Ⅱ, Hitachi, Japan) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM, JEM200CX, JEOL, Japan). The BET surface area and pore size distribution were determined from N2 adsorption at 77 K with a NOVE-2000E surface area analyzer. The elemental composition was obtained using an Xray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). XPS measurements were performed on a PHI 5000 VersaProbe XPS system (ULVAC-PHI, Japan). The surface functional groups were determined by Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR). The FTIR spectra were recorded on a Thermo Fisher spectrum in the 4000–400 cm−1 region with a resolution of 2 cm−1.

sections.heading: 2.3. Adsorption experiments
sections.text:
Batch adsorption experiments were performed according to the polyoxymethylene-solid phase extraction (POM-SPE) method developed by Jonker and Koelmans [21] with slight modifications. Briefly, a certain amount of graphene nanomaterials (10mg for GN; 30mg for GO and SG) were weighted into 300mL all-glass bottles filled with 290mL of background solutions. The background solutions were prepared with deionized water consisting of 0.01M calcium chloride and 200mg L−1 sodium azide as biocide. The pH of the aqueous solutions in the bottles was adjusted to 7.0 ± 0.1 with 0.1 M NaOH and 0.1M HCl solution. Mixed stock solutions of six PCB congeners in acetone were then spiked to the bottles to acquire six initial concentrations within the range of 0.5–50 µg L−1 (individual congener concentration). Meanwhile, the volume of acetone (spiking solvent) in aqueous solutions was kept below 0.1% (v/v) in order to prevent cosolvent effect. The POM strips
(0.5 g) were then added to the bottles. The bottles containing only POM strips and sorbents in background solutions without PCBs were also conducted as control samples. Each treatment was performed in triplicates. All bottles were covered with thread caps equipped with silicone/polytetrafluoroethylene septa and placed on an incubated horizontal shaker at 100 rpm at 298.15 K for 4 weeks, which was proved to be sufficient to reach adsorption equilibrium by our preliminary kinetic experiments and other studies [13].
Subsequently, the POM strips were collected from the bottles, rinsed with deionized water, wiped with moist tissues to remove any sorbent material on the POM surface. The strips were then Soxhlet-extracted with 70mL of methanol for 3 h. Extracts were evaporated to near dryness in a rotary evaporator and redissolved in hexane. Thereafter, the extracts were cleaned up over composite columns successively enclosed with silica gel, neutral aluminum oxide and anhydrous sodium sulfate (w/w=2:2:1). For the experiments concerning the pH influence, the initial solution pH was adjusted to 4.0 and 10.0, respectively. To investigate the impact of temperature, the batch equilibrium experiments were performed at other two temperatures, namely 283.15 and 313.15 K.
The PCB concentration in the extracts were measured using an Agilent 6890 gas-chromatograph, equipped with 63Ni electron capture detector. Samples were separated by a 30m DB-5MS capillary column (diameter 250 µm and film thickness 0.25 µm, Agilent, USA), with ultrahigh purity helium gas as carrier gas at a constant flow of 1.0 mLmin−1. The inlet and detector temperature were both set at 300 °C. A temperature program was run from 120 °C (1min hold), increased by 20 °Cmin−1 to 210 °C (3min hold), increased by 3 °Cmin−1 to 230 °C (4min hold), increased by 30 °Cmin−1 to 270 °C and held for 6min.

sections.heading: 2.4. Data analysis
sections.text: The adsorption amounts were calculated based on the equilibrium partition of PCBs among the three phases (aqueous solution, POM and sorbents) (detailed in the SI). Adsorption isotherms of PCBs on three graphene nanomaterials were fitted to two typical isotherm models: Freundlich and Langmuir. More details about the two models and the calculation of thermodynamic parameters are presented in the SI. All adsorption data were expressed as the mean ± standard deviation (SD) of triplicates. Model parameters were estimated using the nonlinear regression option in Origin 8.0. Statistical analysis was performed by SPSS 16.0 variance analysis software.

sections.heading: 3.1. Characterization of graphene nanomaterials
sections.text:
The microstructures of three graphene nanomaterials were observed by SEM and TEM, and the representative images are presented in Fig. 1. A large number of irregular wrinkles were loosely distributed on the surface of GN, which confirmed the nature of graphene (Fig. 1.A). Compared with GN, the surfaces of GO and SG were relatively flat, and revealed crumpled leaf-like nanosheets with some ripples (Fig. 1.B, C). All the TEM images demonstrated that the nanosheets films of GN, GO and SG were transparent and some corrugation and scrolling formed on the basal planes (Fig. 1.D, E, F).
The results of element composition and BET analysis for three graphene nanomaterials are shown in Table 1. As expected, GN has the highest percent carbon (89.39%), followed by GO (65.93%) and SG (45.59%). Correspondingly, the presence of surface functional groups resulted in higher amounts of oxygen in SG (37.05%) and GO (32.00%) than GN (9.96%). Additionally, a 7.78 percent of sulfur could be detected within the atomic structure of SG, significantly more than that in GO and GN, preliminarily suggesting the successful introduction of sulfur to graphene nanosheets. The BET specific surface areas of GN, GO
and SG were 278.9, 237.7 and 193.5 m2/g, respectively, which are all significantly greater than graphite (4.5 m2/g) [30], revealing the exfoliation degree of graphene nanomaterials. However, the surface area of these three graphene nanomaterials were each lower than the theoretical values suggested by the supplier, which should result from their aggregation state. GN had an average pore diameter of 54.66 nm, belonging to macroporous material, while the two functionalized graphene nanomaterials were all mesoporous, with average pore diameters of 17.92 and 23.23 nm for GO and SG, respectively; However, the total pore volume of GN was nearly eight times as much as that of GO and SG, endowing GN more interaction sites with sorbates.
As demonstrated in FTIR spectra (Fig. 1G), for SG and GO, the strong bands at 3405 and 3397 cm−1 were attributed to the stretching vibration of eOH. For SG, the peak at 1185 and 1038 cm−1 was ascribed to SeO vibration and S-phenyl vibration, confirming the presence of sulfonic acid groups in SG. Moreover, these peaks are absent in the spectra of GO and GN. The peak at 1571 cm−1 was assigned to the C]C skeletal vibrations. For GO, more oxygen-containing functional groups could be ascertained from the appearance of relative peaks,
a Specific surface area calculated with the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) model.
b Total pore volume. c Average pore diameter.
including C]O, carboxyl O]CeO and alkoxy CeO bonds whose skeletal vibration led to the peaks at 1715, 1385 and 1066 cm−1, respectively. Compared with GO and SG, the intensity of the peaks corresponding to the skeletal vibration of oxygen-containing function groups were obviously weakened, such as the OeH bond at 3446 cm−1, the carboxyl O]CeO bond at 1398 cm−1 and the CeOeC bond at 1212 cm−1. This revealed that only a few polar functional groups appeared on the surface of GN, and thereby the surface of GN is highly hydrophobic.

sections.heading: 3.2. Adsorption isotherms of PCBs on graphene nanomaterials
sections.text:
Adsorption isotherms and model fitting were constructed for all sorbent-congener combinations except GN, for which isotherm data were not generated for two planar PCB congeners (PCB 77, 126), because less than 3 isotherm points were adequately obtained (Fig. 2). According to R2 (Table S2) and standard errors of fitting parameters (Table 2), Freundlich equation was considered as the suitable model for fitting the adsorption of PCBs on the three graphene nanomaterials.
More details can be referred to the SI. The Freundlich coefficient n values of GN were significantly much lower than those of GO and SG, suggesting that GN possessed a more heterogeneous surface than GO and SG [15], which was supported by the SEM and TEM images that reflected more morphological wrinkles and folds in GN in comparison to GO and SG (Fig. 1).
As could be observed from Fig. 2, GN had the strongest adsorption ability, much higher than GO and SG, regardless of the specific congener as the adsorbate. Interestingly, GO and SG demonstrated quite comparable adsorption over the present concentration range, with the exception of PCB77 adsorption at the higher concentrations, for which the adsorption amounts on SG were slightly higher than those on GO by an average of 0.40 log units. These results illustrated that no significant influence occurred for the adsorption of PCBs on graphene oxide after introduction of sulfonic group, which were inconsistent with earlier researches demonstrating that the introduction of sulfonic group significantly promoted the dispersibility of graphene [31], extended potential adsorption sites and were consequently able to serve as a superb adsorbent for some specific pollutants, including PAHs (naphthalene
and phenanthrene) [31], 1-naphthol [32], methylene blue and heavy metals (Cd2+) [33]. The differences were probably due to the stronger hydrophobicity of PCBs (log Kow= 5.60–6.89), significantly far higher than these reported compounds (2.85, 3.33 and 4.57 for naphthalene, phenanthrene, and 1-naphthol, respectively).
Hydrophobic organic pollutants could be adsorbed to carbon based nanomaterials through a combination of hydrophobic interactions and π-π interactions, and thus the adsorption was highly dependent on specific surface area [9,18]. In order to account for the contribution of surface area to the adsorption on graphene nanomaterials, all the isotherm data were normalized with the specific surface area of corresponding adsorbent (Fig. S1). Surface area normalization reduced the differences in adsorption capacities between GN and GO or SG, revealing that specific surface area plays a certain role on the adsorption of PCBs on graphene nanomaterials. Nevertheless, GN still had a greater adsorption amount than GO or SG. Therefore, we deduced that there were other mechanisms accounting for the adsorption difference. A better fit of adsorption isotherm on GN with Langmuir model suggested that monolayer adsorption might occur on GN surface (Details shown in SI). Supposing that all the PCBs congeners were adsorbed on the surface of the three graphene nanomaterials, we could calculate the percent of adsorbent surface area covered by PCBs based on the total adsorbed ∑PCB amount and the molecular surface areas of PCB congeners (Table S1), the maximum percent coverage of the three adsorbents would be 16.5, 6.5 and 7.9% for GN, GO and SG respectively. This suggested that surface adsorption contributed for the adsorption on GN to a larger extent [24]. Meanwhile, surface coverage areas of> 35% was considered to cause competitive effects on the adsorbent surface [28], therefore, we could confirm that no competitive effects occurred on the three graphene nanomaterials even at the highest concentrations in the present study.

sections.heading: 3.3. Planarity effect of PCBs adsorption on graphene nanomaterials
sections.text:
PCB distribution coefficients, Kd values, were calculated at different equilibrium aqueous concentrations ranging from 0.01 to 1000 ng L−1 (Fig. 3). The three graphene nanomaterials processed log Kd values ranging from 4.8 to 8.6. The range was similar to previous studies referring to the adsorption of investigated PCB congeners on activated carbon [23] and other PCBs congeners on carbon nanomaterials [13].
The stair step pattern presented in Fig. 3A, B, C, D reveals that the
adsorption of PCBs congeners on the three graphene nanomaterials displayed obvious planarity effect at the lower concentrations (0.01–10 ng L−1). PCB54, the most nonplanar congener with 4 ortho chlorine substituents in the present study, has the lowest adsorption affinity on the three graphene nanomaterials. As the number of ortho chlorine substituents decreased, the adsorption affinity of PCBs congeners showed an evident increase. The log Kd values of PCB53 adsorption, which has similar hydrophobicity to PCB54 (Table S1), were 1.1, 1.5 and1.2 times higher than those of PCB54 on GN, GO and SG at aqueous concentration of 0.01 ng L−1 (Fig. 3A), rather than identical values in the condition of pure hydrophobic adsorption. The planar congeners, PCB77 and PCB126, were found to have a greater affinity towards GO and SG, with an average of 1.4 and 1.7 times higher than PCB54 at aqueous concentration of 0.01 ng L−1. These could be understood due to the fact that π-π interaction was considered as one of the most important adsorption mechanisms [13,23,24]. Besides, hydrogen bonding and hydrophobic interaction also contributed to the total adsorption [9,16,34]. We considered that the degree of planarity effect was dependent on the relative contribution ratio of hydrophobic interaction and other adsorption mechanisms.
At lower concentrations, PCB congeners exist in the aqueous solutions with relatively less hydrophobic functional groups in the adsorption system (mainly in the dissolved state), thereby leading to the weaker hydrophobic interaction compared with other mechanisms [18]. π-π interactions or hydrogen bonds became the main driving force of the interaction between PCB molecules and graphene surface. For PCB congeners with similar hydrophobicity, as the number of ortho chlorines decreased and thus the PCB molecule tended to be planar with less twisting of biphenyl rings, the steric hindrances between PCB congeners and the surface of graphene nanomaterials were attenuated [22], and thereby the adsorption was strengthened.
However, with the increase of aqueous concentration of PCB congeners, the planarity effects were gradually diminishing, which was in accordance with previous research about the planarity effect of PCBs adsorption on activated carbon [23], whereas no explanation was provided. We believed these could be due to the different dominating mechanism at lower and high concentrations. With the increase of PCB concentrations, the contribution of surface adsorption and partition was gradually increasing, especially on GO and SG. For example, at relatively high aqueous concentration of 100 ng L−1, the monolayer surface area coverage would be 73 and 71% for PCB adsorption on GO and SG,
respectively. It could be deduced that the coverage would be more than 73% according to the more contribution of surface adsorption and larger adsorption amount on GN as discussed above. These results meant that competitive effects would occur when PCBs were adsorbed to the surface of graphene nanomaterials (if surface coverage area> 35% as discussed above) at the higher aqueous concentrations [28]. In this situation, we hypothesize that PCB congeners with stronger hydrophobicity (PCB77 or PCB126) would be firstly adsorbed to the adsorption sites at the surface of graphene nanomaterials. Subsequently, the progressive adsorption of PCBs might change the site density and heterogeneity, and π-π interactions would be likely weakened [18]. Meanwhile, the progressive adsorption would also provide more hydrophobic sorption sites for the PCB congeners with weaker adsorption performance. In that case, hydrophobic interaction might be more important and consequently planarity effect would be suppressed.

sections.heading: 3.4. Influence of graphene characteristics on planarity effect of PCBs adsorption
sections.text:
On the basis of the log Kd values presented in Fig. 3, the general progression of adsorption affinity for the smaller and less hydrophobic PCB congeners is as follows: GN > SG > GO. As the molecular size and hydrophobicity increased, the log Kd values for the three graphene nanomaterials converged toward similar especially at concentrations of 0.01 and 0.1 ng L−1. Moreover, as the aqueous concentrations of PCBs increased, GO and SG tended to have identical adsorption affinity for less hydrophobic PCB congeners, and the difference in the adsorption affinity between GN and GO or SG were gradually shrunk.
Particularly interesting of all, the planarity effect of PCB adsorption differed with the species of graphene nanomaterials or, more specially, surface functional groups. To clearly illustrate this observation, we quantified the planarity effect by accounting for the change in log Kd between tetra-ortho and tri-ortho groups (Δlog Kd) [13]. GO illustrated the greatest effect, especially at the lowest aqueous concentration (0.01 ng L−1), followed by SG and last GN, with values ranging from
−0.14 to 2.37, 0.16 to 1.23, and −0.16 to 0.88, respectively. These results suggested that hydrophobic interaction contributed more to the adsorption on GN, which complied with the discussion above. While both π-π interaction and hydrogen bonding would make more contributions to the adsorption of PCB congeners on GO and SG, due to the existence of oxygen containing functional groups.

sections.heading: 3.5. Influence of pH on planarity effect of PCBs adsorption
sections.text:
The change of pH induced significantly differential effect on both types of functionalized graphene, GO and SG. According to R2 (Table S4) and the relative standard errors (Table S5), Freundlich model was more suitable for fitting the isotherm data at pH 4.0 and 10.0 than Langmuir model. Moreover, the n values for the isotherms on GO, were demonstrated to significantly decrease from 0.95–2.31 at pH 7.0 to 0.54–0.68 and 0.52–0.95 at pH 4.0 and 10.0, respectively. This suggested that GO became more heterogeneous under acidic or alkaline conditions, facilitating the surface adsorption of PCB congeners. However, no obvious variation was observed from the n values for the isotherms on SG under different pH conditions. The lack of pH-dependence of PCBs adsorption on SG ruled out the importance of π-π interactions, as demonstrated by weaker planarity effect on SG (Fig. 3).
The adsorption of PCBs on SG could be observed to be independent from solution pH except two coplanar congeners (PCB77 and PCB126) (Fig. S2). The change of solution pH suppressed the adsorption of both coplanar congeners on SG, revealing their important interactions with oxygen-containing functional groups, such as hydrogen bonds. Interestingly, the adsorption of PCBs on GO was significantly promoted at a certain concentration range under acidic or alkaline conditions (Fig. S3), except both coplanar congeners. Based on pH-independent molecular speciation of PCBs [16], we speculated that solution pH might affect the dissociation of oxygen-containing functional groups on graphene surfaces, further influencing the existing state of graphene in solution. The measurement of the size distribution of both graphene nanoparticles in solutions under different pH conditions confirmed our
inference. As has been expected, the up or down-regulation of solution pH exerted a limited impact on dispersion of SG in adsorption system, while significantly reduced the particle size of GO (Fig. S4). In other words, compared with neutral condition, acidic and alkaline conditions were both more favorable to the dispersion of GO particles in solution and acidic condition was preferable, which was similar to the influence of pH on the aggregation of graphene quantum dots (GODs) [35]. In acidic solutions, GO was prone to be protonated and thus the polycyclic aromatic network of GO became more hydrophobic, contributing to GO-water-GO self-assembly and subsequently high stability of GO at low pH levels [36]. However, in alkaline conditions, the oxygen-containing functional groups became ionized, thereby increasing the negative charge between GO nanosheets and suspended in solution at a relatively stabilized state due to the strong electrostatic repulsion [37]. Sufficient dispersion expanded the adsorption sites of GO for PCBs, thereby facilitating the adsorption of PCBs on GO.
In addition to graphene types, the influencing extent of solution pH on the adsorption of PCBs to GO was highly dependent on PCB species. As has been shown in Fig. 4, the promotion degree of solution pH adjustment on PCB adsorption on GO in the concentration range of 0.01 to 1 ng L−1 complied with the following order: PCB54 > PCB28 > PCB18 > PCB53 > PCB77 > PCB126, just opposite to the adsorption ability of these PCB congeners on GO (Fig. S2), which was directly correlated with the planarity of PCB congeners. Therefore, these naturally led to the attenuation of the planarity effect on adsorption of PCB
congeners on GO at lower concentrations (0.01–10 ng L−1) under acidic or alkaline conditions, compared with neutral condition (Fig. 4A–D). However, the impact of pH change on the planarity effect on SG was quite limited, and only alkaline condition slightly weakened the planarity effect at lower concentrations (Fig. 4G–L).
It has been demonstrated above that more sorption sites of GO nanoparticles would be released under acidic or alkaline solutions (Fig. S4). Under acidic conditions, along with protonation, more hydrophobic surface of GO nanoparticles were prone to be approached by PCBs through hydrophobic interactions, thereby facilitating the development of π-π interaction between the aromatic structure of GO and benzene rings of PCB congeners [9]. Moreover, the protonation was in favor of the extensive hydrogen bonding between the oxygen-containing functional groups of GO and PCB molecules [38]. In the whole process, hydrophobic interaction became more important for the adsorption, and thus attenuated the planarity effect on the adsorption of PCBs to GO. Whereas under alkaline solutions, the more deprotonation of surface functional groups caused stronger electrostatic repulsion among GO nanoparticles [39], resulting in increased release of surface adsorption sites and enhanced binding of PCB molecules with GO surface functional groups.

sections.heading: 3.6. Influence of temperature on planarity effect of PCBs adsorption
sections.text:
The effect of temperature on the adsorption of PCBs was dependent on PCB variety, concentration and graphene type (Fig. 5). Within the
concentration range of 0.01–10 ng L−1, the temperature increase facilitated the adsorption of PCB congeners on GO in some degrees except PCB53, which remained nearly constant at three different temperatures. The promotion degree of the temperature increase on the adsorption of PCB18, PCB28, and PCB54 was far higher than that of coplanar congeners, and gradually decreased as the concentration increased. Interestingly, when the equilibrium concentrations were above 100 ng L−1, the temperature change generated completely opposite effect to those at lower concentrations, that is, lower temperature facilitated the adsorption of PCBs on GO (Fig. 5E and F). At lower concentrations, elevated temperature would greatly enhance the interaction between PCB molecule and graphene surface [40], which made main contributions to the adsorption. Nevertheless, at higher concentrations, there are significant competition for the adsorption of different PCB congeners. In this case, the number of accessible adsorption sites would be more important. Elevated temperature has been proved to cause the agglomeration of graphene [41], and thereby hinder the adsorption of PCBs. In most realistic conditions, PCBs are distributed in contaminated waters at lower concentrations, and thus the increase of temperature are beneficial for the adsorption of PCBs on graphene.
The effect of temperature on the adsorption of PCBs on both types of functionalized graphene remained similar promotion trend at lower concentrations. However, the promotion degree on SG was obviously lower than that on GO (Fig. 5G–I). For example, the lg Kd value for the adsorption of PCB54 on SG was increased by 2.31 log unit with the increase of temperature from 283.15 K to 313.15 K at the concentration
of 0.01 ng L−1, almost 51% lower than the promotion degree on GO. However, the concentration range, in which the adsorption on SG was enhanced with the increase of temperature, became narrower, e.g. from 0.01 to 1 ng L−1. At the concentration of 10 ng L−1, there were almost not difference among the lg Kd values for the adsorption of PCB18, PCB28 and PCB54 at three different temperatures. When the concentration was increased above 100 ng L−1, the adsorption of all PCB congeners on SG were reduced with the increase of temperature, which was similar to that on GO.
It could be clearly observed that the degree of planarity effect for the adsorption of PCBs on graphene nanoparticles were temperaturedependent (Fig. 5). Whatever type of graphene it is, the Δlog Kd significantly decreased with the increase of the temperature. For instance, at the lower concentration of 0.01 ng L−1, the Δlog Kd values for GO and SG decreased from 3.49 and 1.71 at 283.15 K to 2.37 and 1.19 at 298.15 K and finally to −0.75 and −0.13 at 313.15 K, respectively. At 313.15 K, the planarity effect almost disappeared, especially for the adsorption on SG, the lg Kd values for all six PCB congeners were nearly in alignment. These results suggested that low temperature promoted the planarity effect of the adsorption on GO or SG, while warming resulted in the suppression on the planarity effect. These might be attributed to the temperature-dependent π-π interaction. The variation of temperature have been reported to cause the change of π-π stacking patterns [42]. At the lower temperature, the π-π stacking interaction was mainly present in the form of face-to-face configuration, which was relatively strong and stable, whereas it would transform to offset
stacking form or edge-to-face stacking form with the increase of temperature, and the π-π stacking interaction was even subsequently disrupted, resulting in the disappearance of planarity effect at 313.15 K. These phenomena strongly indicates that π-π interactions are the primary interaction in the adsorption mechanisms as well, which supported the viewpoint above.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusion
sections.text: GN showed stronger adsorption ability toward PCB congeners in comparison with GO and SG. The planarity effect exhibiting in the adsorption of PCB congeners on all three graphene nanomaterials was dependent on PCB concentrations, graphene characteristics, solution pH and temperature. With the increasing aqueous concentration of PCB congeners, the planarity effect was gradually weakening and even disappearing. Surface functionalization of graphene significantly promoted the planarity effect. Both acidic and alkaline conditions notably suppressed the planarity effect of PCB adsorption on GO at lower concentrations (0.01–10 ng L−1), while only alkaline condition slightly weakened the planarity effect on SG at lower concentrations. Lower temperature was favorable for the planarity effect of PCBs adsorption on GO or SG, and the increase of temperature evidently attenuated the planarity effect.
